name: Sexual Transmission
description: Spread through sexual contact with an HIV-infected person.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through sexual contact with an HIV-infected person.", "name": "Sexual Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through sexual contact with an HIV-infected person.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract clearly indicates that sexual contact is a predominant means of HIV transmission, which leads to AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:1396037", "snippet": "The virus is transmitted predominantly through genital sexual contact, although orogenital spread has been rarely reported.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract states that HIV (which leads to AIDS) can be transmitted through genital or anogenital sexual intercourse.", "reference": "PMID:2659680", "snippet": "The probability that any single episode of genital-genital or anogenital sexual intercourse will result in transmission of HIV may be determined by multiple biologic factors of the infectious person, the virus itself, and the exposed susceptible person.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The review confirms that sexual contact is a primary mode of HIV transmission, leading to AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:3539811", "snippet": "HIV spreads... by infected needles among i.v. drug users and, more rarely, among health care workers, but mainly by sexual contact.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "Sexual contact in the context of multiple sexual partners leads to a higher risk of contracting HIV, which causes AIDS.", "reference": "PMID:2004869", "snippet": "The migrant labor system has created a market for prostitution in mining towns and geographic networks of relationships within and between urban and rural communities... appear especially vulnerable to contracting HIV infection since they are involved in multiple sexual encounters with different, changing partners, usually without condom protection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Sexual Transmission"}

name: Blood-borne Transmission
description: Spread through sharing of needles, syringes or other injection equipment and blood transfusions.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through sharing of needles, syringes or other injection equipment and blood transfusions.", "name": "Blood-borne Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through sharing of needles, syringes or other injection equipment and blood transfusions.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference title suggests it is about sharing of needles among users of intravenous drugs, but no abstract is provided.", "reference": "PMID:3945272", "snippet": "", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "This reference provides data supporting blood-borne transmission, primarily through transfusions.", "reference": "PMID:2720234", "snippet": "As of August 1988, 1,628 cases of AIDS had been reported in Mexico, of which 12% were ascribed to transmission through blood.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms transmission via infected needles and blood products.", "reference": "PMID:3539811", "snippet": "HIV spreads by vertical transmission and by iatrogenic transmission (transfer of blood or blood-containing products), by infected needles among i.v. drug users and, more rarely, among health care workers, but mainly by sexual contact.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference emphasizes the importance of needle-sharing in HIV transmission.", "reference": "PMID:3650679", "snippet": "The sharing of needles and syringes by intravenous drug abusers has been recognized as a critical factor in the transmission of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference provides survey data indicating knowledge about transmission through blood transfusions and shared needles.", "reference": "PMID:1283669", "snippet": "Most of them knew that promiscuity, blood transfusion and sharing injection needles and syringes are the major modes of transmission.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by discussing the promotion of safer needle practices to prevent AIDS transmission.", "reference": "PMID:3329446", "snippet": "In the absence of a vaccine that would prevent AIDS or of medicines that would cure it, the primary strategies of such agencies have focused on reducing the spread of AIDS by promoting cessation of high risk behaviors... promoting the use of new or sterilized syringes and needles among those who will not abstain from drug use.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference provides a case study supporting transmission through blood transfusion.", "reference": "PMID:6132270", "snippet": "An infant who received multiple transfusions during the first few days of life for rhesus disease became ill with recurrent infections when 6 months old... It was determined that one of the blood donors, who was well at the time of blood donation, had died 17 months after with multiple opportunistic infections and acquired immunodeficiency.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Blood-borne Transmission"}

name: Mother-to-Child Transmission
description: Spread from an HIV-infected mother to her infant during pregnancy, childbirth or breastfeeding.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread from an HIV-infected mother to her infant during pregnancy, childbirth or breastfeeding.", "name": "Mother-to-Child Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread from an HIV-infected mother to her infant during pregnancy, childbirth or breastfeeding.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract details all the mentioned modes of transmission from an HIV-infected mother to her infant.", "reference": "PMID:9067788", "snippet": "Mother-to-infant HIV transmission has been reported to occur during pregnancy (in utero), at delivery, or postpartum (breast feeding).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference confirms that mother-to-child transmission includes pregnancy, delivery, and breastfeeding.", "reference": "PMID:9211414", "snippet": "Children who become infected with HIV-1 acquire the infection almost exclusively from their mothers during pregnancy or delivery, or via breast feeding.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract emphasizes the significance of mother-to-child transmission, though it does not detail the modes.", "reference": "PMID:36355599", "snippet": "More than 90% of all HIV infections in children result from mother to child transmission.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference explains the mechanism of mother-to-child transmission, further validating the statement.", "reference": "PMID:9764363", "snippet": "Sexual and mother-to-child transmission of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) type 1 occurs only with a low percentage of infection. ... We have studied the mechanism of transmission from mother to child, by analyzing the cell-to-cell transmission in the trophoblast. ... confirming the cell-to-cell transmission between the mother and child and not a true vertical transmission through the germinal lines.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Mother-to-Child Transmission"}

name: Respiratory Droplets
description: Spread through close contact with an infected person, such as coughing or sneezing.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through close contact with an infected person, such as coughing or sneezing.", "name": "Respiratory Droplets"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through close contact with an infected person, such as coughing or sneezing.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The provided reference does not mention the spread of bacterial meningitis through respiratory droplets or close contact.", "reference": "PMID:22667193", "snippet": "Bacterial meningitis is often difficult to recognize since the classical presentation with neck stiffness, reduced awareness and fever occurs in less than half of the patients. The only way to diagnose or exclude bacterial meningitis is by performing low-threshold cerebrospinal fluid examination with a suspicion of bacterial meningitis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The focus is on chemoprophylaxis and nasopharyngeal carriage but does not provide direct evidence regarding transmission through respiratory droplets.", "reference": "PMID:8449848", "snippet": "Chemoprophylaxis can be used only for the prevention of secondary cases once an index case has been identified. The objectives of prophylaxis are threefold: (i) to eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage in household contacts; (ii) to prevent contacts from acquiring the disease and (iii) to treat infection in those incubating the disease.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}, {"explanation": "The reference discusses the causes and impacts of Haemophilus influenzae but does not provide information on the transmission of bacterial meningitis through respiratory droplets.", "reference": "PMID:31981610", "snippet": "H. influenzae type b is the leading cause of bacterial meningitis in children before introduction of vaccination and is a common cause of pneumonia, epiglottis and septic arthritis.", "supports": "NO_EVIDENCE"}], "name": "Respiratory Droplets"}

name: Triatomine fecal contamination during blood feeding
description: Infected triatomines release metacyclic trypomastigotes in feces during blood meals.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Infected triatomines release metacyclic trypomastigotes in feces during blood meals.", "name": "Triatomine fecal contamination during blood feeding"}
raw_json: {"description": "Infected triatomines release metacyclic trypomastigotes in feces during blood meals.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract links transmission to triatomine blood feeding and fecal contamination.", "reference": "PMID:18512345", "snippet": "While feeding on host's blood, infected triatomines release in their feces highly motile and infective metacyclic trypomastigotes that may initiate infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Triatomine fecal contamination during blood feeding"}

name: Aedes mosquito transmission
description: Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus transmit chikungunya virus.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus transmit chikungunya virus.", "name": "Aedes mosquito transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus transmit chikungunya virus.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract specifies Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus as vectors.", "reference": "PMID:29533749", "snippet": "Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) is an arthropod-borne alphavirus, transmitted by Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Aedes mosquito transmission"}

name: Fecal-Oral Transmission
description: Spread through ingestion of contaminated water or food.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through ingestion of contaminated water or food.", "name": "Fecal-Oral Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through ingestion of contaminated water or food.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This statement supports the idea that cholera is spread through ingesting contaminated water or food and aligns with the principle of fecal-oral transmission.", "reference": "PMID:10892490", "snippet": "Cholera is a highly contagious disease, and is transmitted primarily by ingestion of faecally-contaminated water by susceptible persons. Besides water, foods have also been recognized as an important vehicle for transmission of cholera.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This explicitly states that cholera is transmitted via ingestion of contaminated water or food, supporting the idea of fecal-oral transmission.", "reference": "PMID:36634024", "snippet": "Cholera, which is transmitted through ingestion of water or food contaminated with fecal matter...", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the transmission of cholera through contaminated water or food, aligning with fecal-oral transmission.", "reference": "PMID:36573678", "snippet": "Cholera is a diarrheal infection caused by ingested water or food contaminated with the bacterium Vibrio cholerae.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This suggests that contaminated water, a route fitting fecal-oral transmission, was a primary factor in the outbreak, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:33753586", "snippet": "This ADD outbreak was likely associated with drinking contaminated groundwater, which probably occurred after heavy rainfall in an area of open defecation.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Fecal-Oral Transmission"}

name: Direct Contact
description: Can spread through direct contact with infected individuals or their bodily fluids.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Can spread through direct contact with infected individuals or their bodily fluids.", "name": "Direct Contact"}
raw_json: {"description": "Can spread through direct contact with infected individuals or their bodily fluids.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "This study reports an outbreak of cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae O1 in a psychiatric hospital in Singapore and demonstrates that the transmission occurred through close person-to-person contact.", "reference": "PMID:2341728", "snippet": "Extensive epidemiological investigations showed that the organism was not transmitted by contaminated food or water but through close person-to-person contact.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study demonstrates a significant role of direct transmission within households during cholera outbreaks in Bangladesh.", "reference": "PMID:25411971", "snippet": "Significant direct transmission (p-value<0.0001) occurred among 1414 members of 364 households.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference mentions that close contact with a patient can result in contamination and transmission of cholera.", "reference": "PMID:30512613", "snippet": "Contamination is by ingestion, due to close contact with a patient, or by contaminated water and food.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study discusses the transmission of cholera from person to person in endemic settings.", "reference": "PMID:29174695", "snippet": "Cholera is known to be transmitted from person to person.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Direct Contact"}

name: Environmental Reservoirs
description: Vibrio cholerae can survive in aquatic environments, potentially leading to outbreaks.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Vibrio cholerae can survive in aquatic environments, potentially leading to outbreaks.", "name": "Environmental Reservoirs"}
raw_json: {"description": "Vibrio cholerae can survive in aquatic environments, potentially leading to outbreaks.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms that Vibrio cholerae can survive in aquatic environments during inter-epidemic periods and discusses the role of environmental reservoirs in cholera transmission.", "reference": "PMID:31285087", "snippet": "While the bacteria can be isolated from both clinical and environmental sources during epidemics, it evades isolation by conventional culture techniques during the period between successive epidemics.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The presence of Vibrio cholerae in riverbed sediments suggests environmental reservoirs can harbor the bacteria and contribute to outbreaks.", "reference": "PMID:28642796", "snippet": "Altogether, 120 samples (60 water and 60 sediment samples) collected from ten sites on the river (January and February 2014) were analysed using PCR. Of the 120 samples, 37 sediment and 31 water samples were positive for at least one of the genes investigated.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The mathematical model incorporates the role of environmental reservoirs in cholera transmission and highlights their significance in maintaining the presence of Vibrio cholerae.", "reference": "PMID:26488620", "snippet": "The environmental compartment, which serves as a source of exposure to toxigenic V. cholerae, is also modeled separately based on the biology of causative bacterium, the shedding of V. cholerae O1 by humans into the environment, as well as the effects of precipitation and water temperature on the concentration and survival of V. cholerae in aquatic reservoirs.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Environmental Reservoirs"}

name: Traumatic skin inoculation

scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Infection typically follows traumatic inoculation of the skin.", "name": "Traumatic skin inoculation"}
raw_json: {"description": "Infection typically follows traumatic inoculation of the skin.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract describes traumatic inoculation as the usual route.", "reference": "PMID:20711281", "snippet": "The infection usually follows traumatic inoculation by a penetrating thorn or splinter wound.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Traumatic skin inoculation"}

name: Dog-associated egg transmission

raw_json: {"description": "Tapeworm eggs from dogs and other canids can infect humans.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract describes transmission of eggs from dogs and other canids to humans.", "reference": "PMID:40944955", "snippet": "Dogs and other canids harboring gut-resident tapeworms readily transmit the tapeworm eggs (and subsequent formation of larval cysts) to humans in close contact with them.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Dog-associated egg transmission"}

name: Contaminated Surfaces

scalar_fields_json: {"description": "The virus can survive on surfaces, infecting individuals through contact with these contaminated surfaces.", "name": "Contaminated Surfaces"}
raw_json: {"description": "The virus can survive on surfaces, infecting individuals through contact with these contaminated surfaces.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While the reference acknowledges the role of environmental contamination and fomite transmission, it indicates that this is an area that requires further study and is not yet conclusively established as a primary mode of transmission.", "reference": "PMID:25698835", "snippet": "Available evidence demonstrates that direct patient contact and contact with infectious body fluids are the primary modes for Ebola virus transmission, but this is based on a limited number of studies. Key areas requiring further study include... (ii) the role of environmental contamination and fomite transmission...", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "name": "Contaminated Surfaces"}

name: Food-borne trematode exposure

scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Infection occurs via food-borne trematodes.", "name": "Food-borne trematode exposure"}
raw_json: {"description": "Infection occurs via food-borne trematodes.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract identifies these infections as food-borne trematodes.", "reference": "PMID:19597009", "snippet": "An estimated 750 million people are at risk of infections with food-borne trematodes, which comprise liver flukes (Clonorchis sinensis, Fasciola gigantica, Fasciola hepatica, Opisthorchis felineus, and Opisthorchis viverrini), lung flukes (Paragonimus spp.), and intestinal flukes (e.g., Echinostoma spp., Fasciolopsis buski, and the heterophyids).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Food-borne trematode exposure"}

name: Blood-borne Transmission
description: Spread through contact with infected blood, including needlesticks and blood transfusions.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through contact with infected blood, including needlesticks and blood transfusions.", "name": "Blood-borne Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through contact with infected blood, including needlesticks and blood transfusions.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature indicates that healthcare workers exposed to blood and body fluids are at risk of hepatitis B, supporting the statement that hepatitis B is spread through contact with infected blood.", "reference": "PMID:9353819", "snippet": "HCWs who are exposed to the blood and body fluids of patients should be required to receive hepatitis B vaccine.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The complications and spread of HBV through blood and other tissues are discussed, supporting the statement about blood-borne transmission.", "reference": "PMID:34806523", "snippet": "HBV can cause severe complications by invading these tissues.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The risk of HBV transmission through tissue transplants supports the idea of blood-borne transmission.", "reference": "PMID:24966613", "snippet": "Cells and tissues are shared between countries which have different regulations and laboratory equipment and represent a risk of hepatitis B virus (HBV) transmission that has become a global safety concern.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The statement about blood-borne transmission is supported by the risk of horizontal transmission through infected blood.", "reference": "PMID:38000801", "snippet": "Neonates experience significant risk from both vertical and horizontal hepatitis B exposure during a period of immaturity of the innate and adaptive immune systems.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature discusses the prevention of HBV through vaccination, indicating its spread through blood contact.", "reference": "PMID:33268600", "snippet": "Although the HBV vaccine can effectively prevent HBV infection, chronic HBV infection still endangers human health and results in a large social burden.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This study documents direct transmission of HBV through surgical procedures, supporting the statement about blood-borne transmission.", "reference": "PMID:23074317", "snippet": "We documented HBV transmission during orthopedic surgery to 2 patients from a surgeon with HBV.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Blood-borne Transmission"}

name: Sexual Transmission
description: Spread through sexual contact with an infected person.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through sexual contact with an infected person.", "name": "Sexual Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through sexual contact with an infected person.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract clearly states that sexual intercourse is a significant mode of transmission for hepatitis B virus in the Western world.", "reference": "PMID:2183516", "snippet": "In the Western world most cases of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection are acquired through sexual intercourse and through needle sharing by intravenous drug users (IVDU).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "While the study indicates that sexual transmission occurs at low levels in Mwanza, Tanzania, it does acknowledge that sexual acquisition of hepatitis B is a route of transmission.", "reference": "PMID:9132977", "snippet": "These findings suggest that sexual acquisition of hepatitis B occurs at low levels in Mwanza, and that HBV can be prevented through enhancement of the current HIV/STD control activities, in addition to improved vaccination strategies.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract emphasizes that sexual transmission of hepatitis B is still a major problem in certain high-risk groups.", "reference": "PMID:15647702", "snippet": "It is clear that sexual transmission of hepatitis B virus is still widespread and is a major problem in certain high-risk groups such as men who have sex with men, intravenous drug users, prisoners and sex workers.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study identifies sexual transmission as an important route for the spread of chronic hepatitis B in Northern Iran.", "reference": "PMID:30415551", "snippet": "Sexual and parent-to-child transmission are important routes of CHB spread in this population from northern Iran despite the fact that 24 years have passed since the beginning of hepatitis B vaccination in infants.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Sexual Transmission"}

name: Mother-to-Child Transmission (Perinatal)
description: Spread from an infected mother to her baby during childbirth.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread from an infected mother to her baby during childbirth.", "name": "Mother-to-Child Transmission (Perinatal)"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread from an infected mother to her baby during childbirth.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The article discusses the transmission of HBV from mother to infant during childbirth, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:29064028", "snippet": "Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection due to perinatal mother-to-infant transmission (MTIT) remains a serious global health problem.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that HBV is commonly transmitted from mother to child.", "reference": "PMID:33574867", "snippet": "The infection is most widely transmitted from the infected mother to a child, with infected blood and body fluids.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article mentions maternal-to-child transmission of HBV, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:37778777", "snippet": "Maternal-to-child transmission of hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis delta virus (HDV) can lead to the risk of progressive liver disease in infants.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by discussing the occurrence of HBV transmission in the perinatal setting.", "reference": "PMID:22510637", "snippet": "Transmission of the hepatitis B virus, despite the availability of the vaccine, still occurs, particularly in the perinatal setting.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study supports the statement by indicating that many chronic HBV cases are due to infections at birth, implying mother-to-child transmission.", "reference": "PMID:31692718", "snippet": "Hepatitis B is a major health concern in Ghana, where prevalence of the virus remains high and most chronic patients are infected during childhood or at birth.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Mother-to-Child Transmission (Perinatal)"}

name: Animal Reservoirs
notes: Rodents and primates are suspected reservoirs; transmission can occur through handling of infected animals.
scalar_fields_json: {"name": "Animal Reservoirs", "notes": "Rodents and primates are suspected reservoirs; transmission can occur through handling of infected animals."}
raw_json: {"evidence": [{"explanation": "The statement is partially supported as rodents and primates are suspected carriers, but the exact nature of their role as reservoirs is not confirmed.", "reference": "PMID:38801572", "snippet": "Recent trends in mpox spread outside the Africa have highlighted increased incidence of spillover of the MPXV from animal to humans. While nature of established animal reservoirs remained undefined, several small mammals including rodents, carnivores, lagomorphs, insectivores, non-human primates, domestic/farm animals, and several species of wildlife are proposed to be carrier of the MPXV infection.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The statement is partially supported since rodents and primates are mentioned as significant in transmission, but the exact nature of their role as reservoirs isn't explicitly confirmed.", "reference": "PMID:36661039", "snippet": "Animal hosts, such as African rodents, mice, prairie dogs, and non-human primates, play important roles in the development and transmission of outbreaks. Laboratory animal infection experiments have demonstrated that some animals are susceptible to mpox virus.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The study indicates orthopoxvirus infections in rodents but did not confirm monkeypox virus. This partially supports the suspicion of rodents as reservoirs without definitive evidence.", "reference": "PMID:36692495", "snippet": "To investigate animal reservoirs of monkeypox virus in Nigeria, we sampled 240 rodents during 2018-2019. Molecular (real-time PCR) and serologic (IgM) evidence indicated orthopoxvirus infections, but presence of monkeypox virus was not confirmed.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}, {"explanation": "The statement is partially supported as it mentions infection in rodents and primates, but does not confirm them as true reservoirs.", "reference": "PMID:36149253", "snippet": "Monkeypox virus can infect several animals, including squirrels, Gambian poached rats, dormice, prairie dogs, monkeys, humans, etc.", "supports": "PARTIAL"}], "name": "Animal Reservoirs", "notes": "Rodents and primates are suspected reservoirs; transmission can occur through handling of infected animals."}

name: Human-to-Human Transmission
notes: Significant during outbreaks, particularly in close-contact settings.
scalar_fields_json: {"name": "Human-to-Human Transmission", "notes": "Significant during outbreaks, particularly in close-contact settings."}
raw_json: {"evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference provides evidence of transmission among humans, particularly through close contact.", "reference": "PMID:35656836", "snippet": "Since May 2022, an outbreak of monkeypox has been ongoing in non-endemic countries. We report four cases in Italy in young adult men reporting condomless sexual intercourse.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference directly mentions human-to-human transmission of monkeypox.", "reference": "PMID:17661673", "snippet": "Since the 1970s, reported monkeypox virus infections of humans have escalated, as have outbreaks with reported human-to-human transmission.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the idea that human-to-human transmission is significant during outbreaks.", "reference": "PMID:37388159", "snippet": "The study findings conclude that traveling can cause the spread of human monkeypox disease in various countries. The findings support the hypothesis that virus sources can travel and spread the disease from person to person and from region to region.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Human-to-Human Transmission", "notes": "Significant during outbreaks, particularly in close-contact settings."}

description: Transmission through contact with body fluids, lesions, or respiratory secretions.

raw_json: {"description": "Transmission through contact with body fluids, lesions, or respiratory secretions.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The reference highlights skin-to-skin contact as a likely mode of transmission, supporting the statement about transmission through direct contact.", "reference": "PMID:36180382", "snippet": "Skin-to-skin contact is the most likely mode of transmission of monkeypox. Precautions to limit skin contact during activities such as breastfeeding are recommended if suspected skin lesions are present.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference mentions direct contact with saliva, respiratory droplets, or skin lesions as modes of transmission, which is in agreement with the statement.", "reference": "PMID:35924502", "snippet": "Transmission is suspected to be direct or indirect via contact with saliva, respiratory droplets or skin lesions of infected animals or more rarely of humans.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Direct Contact"}

name: Fomite Transmission
description: Contact with contaminated clothing, bedding, or other materials.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Contact with contaminated clothing, bedding, or other materials.", "name": "Fomite Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Contact with contaminated clothing, bedding, or other materials.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "While the snippet focuses on direct contact, the overall context supports potential fomite transmission through contaminated materials.", "reference": "PMID:36136939", "snippet": "The risk for monkeypox transmission to health care personnel (HCP) caring for symptomatic patients is thought to be low... Monkeypox typically spreads through close physical (often skin-to-skin) contact with lesions or scabs, body fluids, or respiratory secretions of a person with an active monkeypox infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The literature implies fomite transmission over prolonged contact in a household setting, supporting the concept in the context of contaminated environments.", "reference": "PMID:36564155", "snippet": "We report intrafamilial transmission of monkeypox virus to all members of a family (father, mother, and 2 children).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Fomite Transmission"}

raw_json: {"description": "Spread through inhalation of respiratory droplets from infected individuals.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The abstract indicates that Parvovirus B19 is a respiratory pathogen, which supports the statement that it spreads through inhalation of respiratory droplets.", "reference": "PMID:25283854", "snippet": "It is a common community-acquired respiratory pathogen without ethnic, socioeconomic, gender, age or geographic boundaries", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract mentions that Parvovirus B19 has airborne transmission routes, which supports the statement about respiratory droplets.", "reference": "PMID:35192759", "snippet": "Parvovirus infection (PVI) is widespread, characterized by airborne, bloodborne and vertical transmission routes.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Respiratory Droplets"}

name: Vertical Transmission
description: Transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy.", "name": "Vertical Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study confirms that Parvovirus B19 can be transmitted from mother to fetus during pregnancy, with a vertical transmission rate of 31.7%.", "reference": "PMID:22777688", "snippet": "The vertical transmission rate was 31.7% (20/63).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article explicitly states that Parvovirus B19 is known to cause transplacental (vertical) infections.", "reference": "PMID:38861626", "snippet": "Vertical transmission of an infectious agent is generally defined as transmission from a pregnant individual to their fetus... Parvovirus B19... are also known to cause transplacental infections.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference supports the statement by indicating that Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe outcomes like fetal hydrops, which implies vertical transmission.", "reference": "PMID:17505458", "snippet": "Human parvovirus B19 is a DNA virus with strong tropism for erythroid precursors and infection during pregnancy can result in fetal hydrops and stillbirth.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference supports the statement by detailing the adverse effects of Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy, indicating vertical transmission.", "reference": "PMID:26044725", "snippet": "During pregnancy, this virus is responsible for abortion, fetal anemia. Severe anemia can cause hydrops fetalis or fetal mortality in utero or neurologic damage.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The article reviews the clinical spectrum of intrauterine B19 infection, supporting the concept of vertical transmission.", "reference": "PMID:21351281", "snippet": "In this article, we review the virology, pathology, epidemiology and clinical spectrum of intrauterine human parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection, including intrauterine fetal death, non-immune hydrops fetalis, thrombocytopenia and neurological manifestations.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The review highlights the significant impact of Parvovirus B19 on the developing fetus, indicating vertical transmission.", "reference": "PMID:27235921", "snippet": "Among these are toxoplasmosis, parvovirus B19, and cytomegalovirus. These infections have an important impact on the developing fetus, depending on the timing of infection.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The reference explicitly mentions vertical transmission of Parvovirus B19 and its consequences, such as hydrops fetalis.", "reference": "PMID:18198003", "snippet": "After vertical transmission the infected fetus may develop hydrops fetalis.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Vertical Transmission"}

name: Blood Transfusion
description: Transmission through contaminated blood products.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Transmission through contaminated blood products.", "name": "Blood Transfusion"}
raw_json: {"description": "Transmission through contaminated blood products.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The study identified eight patients who developed parvovirus B19 infection through blood component transfusion, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:21332725", "snippet": "Eight patients with TT-B19V caused by component transfusion have been identified.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The review addresses the potential transmission of parvovirus B19 through blood products, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:9031493", "snippet": "Recent concerns regarding the potential transmission of B19 infection by pooled plasma products.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The abstract mentions that parvovirus B19 can contaminate blood and blood products, supporting the statement.", "reference": "PMID:15645675", "snippet": "Parvovirus B19 is therefore not an uncommon 'contaminant' of blood and blood products.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Blood Transfusion"}

name: Airborne Transmission
description: Spread through the air when individuals with active TB cough, sneeze, or speak.
scalar_fields_json: {"description": "Spread through the air when individuals with active TB cough, sneeze, or speak.", "name": "Airborne Transmission"}
raw_json: {"description": "Spread through the air when individuals with active TB cough, sneeze, or speak.", "evidence": [{"explanation": "The literature confirms airborne transmission of tuberculosis and mentions that direct contact is unimportant in its spread.", "reference": "PMID:6338584", "snippet": "Subsequent evidence has indicated that direct contact is unimportant, although close proximity facilitates airborne transmission.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This excerpt explicitly states that TB is spread by aerosols generated by respiratory activities.", "reference": "PMID:20529335", "snippet": "Tuberculosis is a highly infectious disease that is spread from person to person by infected aerosols emitted by patients with respiratory forms of the disease.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This statement confirms that TB is an airborne disease.", "reference": "PMID:26198113", "snippet": "Tuberculosis (TB) is an airborne disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) that usually affects the lungs leading to severe coughing, fever, and chest pains.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "The study provides empirical evidence of the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in the air, supporting airborne transmission.", "reference": "PMID:34639431", "snippet": "Airborne MTB was detected in 2.2% of samples (13/572), and 97.8% were negative.", "supports": "SUPPORT"}, {"explanation": "This reference also reaffirms that TB is an airborne infectious disease.", "reference": "PMID:30307321", "snippet": "Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious and airborne infectious disease caused by the pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb).", "supports": "SUPPORT"}], "name": "Airborne Transmission"}
